projectInfo.name: Missing Maps - vulnerable villages of Tajikistan - Hakimi, Labidjai
projectInfo.shortDescription: Task: Hakimi, Labidjai. Missing Maps Mapathon for mappers within the global GeoNight. Filling the missing maps of remote villages in a mountainous region of Tajikistan.
projectInfo.description:
Tajikistan is one of the most climate vulnerable countries in Central Asia, frequently experiencing natural disasters that routinely take lives and destroy or degrade land, crops, and infrastructure.
The project “Participatory Mapping in Tajikistan” funded by GIZ and jointly implemented by the NGO Little Earth and CartONG specifically focuses on creating maps and data for supporting adaptation to climate change in remote, mountainous communities of Tajikistan. The Little Erath joined CartONG to become a part of global GeoNight which is held annually on April 9th to fill the missing maps of remote villages in a mountainous regions of Tajikistan.
projectInfo.instructions:
1. Choice of aerial imagery ============ You will use **MAXAR STANDARD** imagery for this project. You have to **select the imagery manually** both on iD Editor and JOSM 2. Buildings ============ * **Be as precise as possible! !** _Zoom in to distinguish buildings. Trace each building as a whole even if it is partly covered by trees on the satellite image._ **How ?** *With the web editor ID:* 1. Use the **polygon** tool to trace buildings 2. Once the building has been plotted, go to the menu on the left and select **"Building"** (this is the generic type that we can use, because we can not know the more specific use of a building from the aerial imagery alone) 3. Finally, correct the right angles by pressing the **"Q" key** ![how to map a building](http://cartong.org/sites/cartong/files/GIF_Building_v2.gif) *With the JOSM editor:* 1. Use the **Draw Nodes** tool to draw buildings or the **buildings_tools** plugin. 2. Trace the building and use the **building = yes** tag 3. Finally, if you use the Draw Nodes tool, remember to correct the angles by pressing the **"Q" key** Warning: Many buildings are very close but in fact do not touch each other, try to draw them close to each other but without connecting them or sharing nodes with other buildings, roads or contours of residential areas. In the iD web editor, when you press the Alt key, you will prevent the nodes from sticking to each other or attaching themselves to a nearby path to accidentally connect to it. 3. Road Network ============ * Please trace clearly identifiable routes that connect to populated areas/isolated houses or other roads. * Connect routes to the existing network whenever it's possible. * Road/Path that do not connect to anything should not be mapped * Overflow slightly from your square so that the person mapping to the next square can easily connect to it. **For this project we will use the following categories:** * **Within a village or residential area** use "Residential Road" (in ID Editor) and "highway=residential" (in JOSM) * **For driveable roads/tracks outside residential areas** use "unmaintained track road" (in ID Editor) and "highway=track" (in JOSM) * **For non driveable paths (less than 1m wide)** use "path" (in ID Editor) and "highway=path" in JOSM) **How ?** *With the web editor ID:* 1. Use the **line** tool to draw the routes 2. Once you have drawn a route, go to the left menu, find the category that corresponds to the typology of the route or path (see definition above) *With the JOSM editor:* 1. Use the **Draw Nodes** tool to trace roads and paths 2. Draw the route and then use the tag corresponding to the typology of it (see definition above) --- 4. Waterways ============ * Please trace clearly identifiable waterways. * Connect waterways to the existing network whenever it's possible. * Overflow slightly from your square so that the person mapping to the next square can easily connect to it. **For this project we will use the following categories:** - For large rivers, use "River" (in ID Editor) and waterway = river (in JOSM) - For smaller streams, use "Stream" (in ID Editor) and waterway = stream (in JOSM) --- **How ?** *With the web editor ID:* 1. Use the **line** tool to draw the routes 2. Once you have drawn a river or a stream, go to the left menu, find the category that corresponds to the typology of waterways (see definition above) *With the JOSM editor:* 1. Use the **Draw Nodes** tool to trace roads and paths 2. Draw the route and then use the tag corresponding to the typology of it (see definition above) --- **The mapping you do makes a real difference**: each of your contributions will not only be used by the organization that requested the project, but will also remain in the database OSM data and visible and reusable by all. Be as specific as possible! **Quality is more important than quantity!** Remember that mapping requires patience, care and attention.

**If you have any questions, please post them in comment**, our volunteers would be happy to answer !
